case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Jalgaon Electric Supply Co., Ltd.

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 477 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 477 of 1957. Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1955,

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated September 9, 1955 of Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37/x of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated September 9, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 37/x of 1954. N. Rajagopal Sastri and D. Gupta, for the appellant.

facts.text: High Court granted certificate for appeal to Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is with a certificate granted by the High Court against its judgment and order dated September 9, 1955, in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian

facts.text: Reference under section 66(1) of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: dated September 9, 1955, in a reference under s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act. The Tribunal had referred the following questions for the decision of the High

facts.text: Tribunal referred two questions: 1. Whether excess dividend declared by assessee? 2. Whether liable for additional income-tax on excess dividend?

anchor.surface_text: Income-tax Act. The Tribunal had referred the following questions for the decision of the High Court Whether there was any excess dividend declared by the assessee Company ? Whether the assessee Company is liable to pay additional income-tax in respect of the excess dividend paid by the assessee Company ?

facts.text: Bombay High Court answered first question affirmatively and second negatively.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the first question in the affirmative and the second, in the negative. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay is the appellant before us,

facts.text: Appellant is Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: negative. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay is the appellant before us, and the Jalgaon Electric Supply Co., Ltd.  the assessee Company  is the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent is Jalgaon Electric Supply Co., Ltd., the assessee company.

anchor.surface_text: us, and the Jalgaon Electric Supply Co., Ltd.  the assessee Company  is the respondent. The facts of the case are simple. For the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51,

facts.text: For assessment year 1949-50, book profits of assessee were Rs. 1,22,469.

anchor.surface_text: The facts of the case are simple. For the assessment years 1949-50 and 1950-51, the book profits of the assessee Company were respectively Rs. 1,22,469 and Rs. 76,886.

facts.text: For assessment year 1950-51, book profits of assessee were Rs. 76,886.

anchor.surface_text: respectively Rs. 1,22,469 and Rs. 76,886. After adjustment of depreciation allowance and other deductions, the income of the assessee Company was finally assessed at Rs.

facts.text: For 1949-50, income assessed at Rs. 3,423 after adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: the assessee Company was finally assessed at Rs. 3,423 and Rs. 3,312 respectively. The assessee Company declared a dividend of Rs. 46,024 in the first year and Rs.

facts.text: For 1950-51, income assessed at Rs. 3,312 after adjustments.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 3,423 and Rs. 3,312 respectively. The assessee Company declared a dividend of Rs. 46,024 in the first year and Rs. 56,326 in the next. The Income-tax Officer,

facts.text: Assessee declared dividend of Rs. 46,024 for 1949-50.

anchor.surface_text: declared a dividend of Rs. 46,024 in the first year and Rs. 56,326 in the next. The Income-tax Officer, applying the Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of the Third and First

facts.text: Assessee declared dividend of Rs. 56,326 for 1950-51.

anchor.surface_text: Rs. 46,024 in the first year and Rs. 56,326 in the next. The Income-tax Officer, applying the Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of the Third and First Schedules of the Finance

facts.text: Income-tax Officer assessed difference to additional income-tax at 5 annas per rupee using Proviso to Para B Part 1 of Finance Acts 1949 and 1950.

anchor.surface_text: next. The Income-tax Officer, applying the Proviso to Para. B of Part 1 of the Third and First Schedules of the Finance Acts, 1949 and 1950 respectively, assessed the difference in each year to additional income-tax, and charged income-tax at the rate of 5 annas in the rupee on the amounts for the two assessment years.

facts.text: Assessee appealed to Appellate Assistant Commissioner then to Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: years. The assessee Company appealed first to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and then to the Tribunal. In the Tribunal, there was a difference of opinion between the President

facts.text: In Tribunal, difference of opinion: President held not liable, Accountant Member held liable; third member agreed with President.

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner and then to the Tribunal. In the Tribunal, there was a difference of opinion between the President and the Accountant Member, the former holding that the assessee Company was number liable and the latter, that it was. The case was then referred to a third Member, who agreed with the President.

facts.text: Tribunal majority reason: no profits brought forward from years preceding the previous year, so paragraphs could not operate.

anchor.surface_text: President. The main reason for the decision of the majority was that there were numberprofits in the years Preceding the previous year, and that, therefore, the said Paragraphs companyld number, on their terms, operate in the circumstances. The view of the minority was that even if there were numberprofits,

facts.text: No profits from years preceding the previous year.

anchor.surface_text: that there were numberprofits in the years Preceding the previous year, and that, therefore, the said Paragraphs companyld number, on their terms, operate in the circumstances.

facts.text: High Court held excess dividends paid but absence of profits from previous years rendered Finance Act unworkable; upheld Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: It may be mentioned at this stage that the decision of the Tribunal turned entirely upon the fact that numberprofits were brought forward from the previous years, and that, therefore, the Paragraphs companyld number be applied. The High Court held that though excess dividends were, in fact, paid, the absence of profits from previous years rendered the Finance Act unworkable in this case.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on May 4, 1960 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: A. Palkhivala, B. K. B. Naidu and 1. N. Shroff. for the respondent. 1960. May 4. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-This appeal is with a certificate

facts.text: Supreme Court agrees with High Court that assessee not liable due to no preceding profits.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the argument of the Commissioner in much the same way as we have done, and we entirely agree with the, reasons given by it. ... The answers given by the High Court to the two questions were companyrect in the circumstances of the case.

facts.text: Excess dividends were paid by assessee.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that though excess dividends were, in fact, paid, the absence of profits from previous years rendered the Finance Act unworkable in this case. It, therefore, accepted the reasons given by the Tribunal, and upheld its decision.

facts.text: Circumstances of two years are similar except amounts.

anchor.surface_text: It may also be pointed out that the circumstances of the two years are also on par, except that the amounts of income and the excess dividends are different.
s. 66 1  of the Indian Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: The fictions which have been introduced postulate that there should be undistributed profits of one or more years immediately preceding the previous year, that such undistributed profits should be sufficient to cover the amount of excess dividend actually paid out in the previous year under assessment, and that the undistributed profits should not have been taken likewise to cover an excess dividend of any other previous year.

concepts.interpretation: Statutory deeming provisions (fictions) in the explanation to the proviso require existence of undistributed profits from preceding years; if absent, fiction wholly fails and no additional tax can be levied

issues.text: Whether the statutory fiction deeming excess dividend to be out of undistributed profits of preceding years applies, and additional income-tax is payable, in the absence of such preceding undistributed profits?

anchor.surface_text: The fictions which have been introduced postulate that there should be undistributed profits of one or more years immediately preceding the previous year, that such undistributed profits should be sufficient to cover the amount of excess dividend actually paid out in the previous year under assessment, and that the undistributed profits should not have been taken likewise to cover an excess dividend of any other previous year.

holdings.text: Where there are no profits of any preceding year or years, the fiction wholly fails and the method of calculation, equally so

anchor.surface_text: Where there are no profits of any preceding year or years, the fiction wholly fails and the method of calculation, equally so. We do not agree with the argument of the Commissioner that the fiction can be given effect to, even if the profits of preceding years do not exist.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Conditions of fiction not met leads to total failure of deeming provision and calculation mechanism

holdings.reasoning_summary: Literal interpretation mandates sequential connection to preceding profits before tax calculation

holdings.text: We do not agree with the argument of the Commissioner that the fiction can be given effect to, even if the profits of preceding years do not exist

anchor.surface_text: We do not agree with the argument of the Commissioner that the fiction can be given effect to, even if the profits of preceding years do not exist. The argument suggests that the chargeability of excess

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects extension of fiction beyond its textual preconditions

holdings.text: The fiction cannot be whittled down in the manner suggested in the first reason. The fiction incorporates within itself not only what the Accountant Member says but also a mode of calculation, which is not a part of the fiction. It is the mode of calculation which cannot be given effect to, though we would go further and say that the fiction itself fails because no profits of preceding years at all existed

anchor.surface_text: The fiction cannot be whittled down in the manner suggested in the first reason. The fiction incorporates within itself not only what the Accountant Member says but also a mode of calculation, which is not a part of the fiction. It is the mode of calculation which cannot be given effect to, though we would go further and say that the fiction itself fails because no profits of preceding years at all existed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects narrowing or partial application; entire fiction and calculation fail without preceding profits

holdings.text: The second reason given by the Accountant Member assumes the liability to pay tax, and that is not permissible, because that is the fact in issue to be decided

anchor.surface_text: The second reason given by the Accountant Member assumes the liability to pay tax, and that is not permissible, because that is the fact in issue to be decided. That fact can only be decided if the Paragraph can be made applicable to the present case and not otherwise.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Circular reasoning rejected as it presupposes the liability under determination

holdings.text: the question of modification of the language cannot arise in the circumstances of the case. Our reasons have been given in Civil Appeal No. 427 of 1957, decided today
holdings.reasoning_summary: Refuses rewriting statute; follows reasoning from companion case

holdings.text: There is also no question of unjustness involved. The Income-tax law seeks to put in the net certain class of income, and can only successfully do so, if it frames a provision appropriate to that end. If the law fails and the tax-payer cannot be brought within its letter no question of unjustness as such, arises
holdings.reasoning_summary: Taxpayer escaping due to legislative gap not unjust; legislature's responsibility

holdings.text: The answers given by the High Court to the two questions were correct in the circumstances of the case

anchor.surface_text: The High Court repelled the argument of the Commissioner in much the same way as we have done, and we entirely agree with the, reasons given by it. ... The answers given by the High Court to the two questions were correct in the circumstances of the case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Full agreement with High Court after independent analysis matching its reasoning

anchor.surface_text: The fiction cannot be whittled down in the manner suggested in the first reason. The fiction incorporates within itself not only what the Accountant Member says but also a mode of calculation, which is not a part of the fiction.
